newsitem.title: USA: Massachusetts in a dither over cookies.
newsitem.headline: Massachusetts in a dither over cookies.

text.p: Whichever way the cookie crumbles, the final decision is sure to be sweet.
Massachusetts Gov. William Weld must decide by July 10 whether to sign or veto legislation, passed Tuesday, designating the tollhouse chocolate chip cookie as the state's official cookie.
The tollhouse was invented in 1930 by a woman at the Toll House Restaurant in Whitman, Massachusetts, who ran out of cocoa while baking chocolate cookies.
But there's a bug in the batter. Weld has his own favourite cookie.
"Several months ago when this was being debated, Gov. Weld threw his weight, which is considerable, behind the Fig Newton," said his deputy press secretary, Ilene Hoffer.
The Nabisco company invented the Fig Newton in Newton, Massachusetts, in 1891.
"You got to stick with Fig Newtons," Weld said in April. "Everybody I knew grew up with Fig Newtons...they're delicious."
Both sides in the weighty issue have tempted the governor to try to tip the scales in their favour, Hoffer said.
"He's been tempted by the Fig Newton people as well as a couple platefuls of tollhouse cookies," she said.
The Boston Globe has asked readers to vote for their own favourite.
